Complete missing values in tables for variables with the proportional relationship y = kx
Read values off a real life graph

explanations.A: I think you have assumed that the gradient needs to be positive and constant. Tom’s graph shows this but does not go through the origin. The ratio between the variables has to be constant for them to be in direct proportion. Which graph(s) show this?
explanations.B: I think you have assumed that the graph doesn’t have to go through (0,0), and needs to have a negative and constant gradient. The ratio between the variables has to be constant for them to be in direct proportion. Which graph(s) show this?
explanations.C: At least one of them is incorrect. What would the y-intercept look like on a graph of direct proportion?
explanations.D: Direct proportion is when two variables are always in the same ratio. Unfortunately, neither graph goes through the origin. Therefore, neither show direct proportion.

explanations.A: Not quite. The relationship between x and y is directly proportional. This means they increase at the same rate. How many times bigger is 30 than 12? The star will be this many times bigger than 7.
explanations.B: I think you have assumed that you would add the same amount on, but variables are directly proportional if they are related through multiplication. First, calculate how many times bigger 30 is than 12. The star will be this many times bigger than 7.
explanations.C: 30/12 = 2.5 and 2.5 x 7 = 17.5. So the star will be 17.5.
explanations.D: I think you have assumed that the values have doubled, but double 12 is NOT 30. How many times bigger is 30 than 12? The star will be this many times bigger than 7.

explanations.A: Not quite. The relationship between x and y is directly proportional. This means they increase at the same rate. How many times bigger is 16.5 than 11? The star will be this many times bigger than 6.
explanations.B: I think you have assumed that you would add the same amount on, but variables are directly proportional if they are related through multiplication. First, calculate how many times bigger 16.5 is than 11. The star will be this many times bigger than 6.
explanations.C: I think you have assumed that the values have doubled, but double 11 is NOT 16.5. How many times bigger is 16.5 than 11? The star will be this many times bigger than 6.
explanations.D: 16.5/11 = 1.5 and 6 x 1.5 = 9. So the star has a value of 9.
